So if you could just introduce yourself, tell us where you are, how old you are and the date today.

And I'm Anna Sosiecki, work for Mencap Cymru and I'm at home in Cardiff.

I know originally you did your interview with Emily.
So we will chat a bit about Emily but it would be good to kind of guess the main focuses around this last few months and how that's impacted you and particularly your friendships and relationships.
So if we start maybe by thinking back to maybe towards the end of February and the build up.
Right yeah.
What was that like for you? Can you describe the sort of run up to things?
I was really, well for me to begin with I was just, I didn't really take it seriously.
Like people around me were saying oh this is going to happen and we're going to have this worldwide thing and you know and I just thought no I don't see it myself.
And then slowly slowly things started to change and I thought hmm maybe I should start taking things more seriously but I just couldn't.
My brain wouldn't allow me to accept the change that was happening even though I knew it was going to happen and I knew I'd have to adjust.
At that moment in time because nobody seemed to panic or everybody around me seemed to panic except for me.
I was a bit like should I be panicked and I thought but then if I start panicking I'm only adding to what's already there and people would ask me why are you not panicking?
Why are you not panicked buying? I said because I don't need to.
I said I don't feel we're at that point where we need to start panicking about what's going on.
I think it really did hit me once we sort of got to start a march and they were like and everything's shut.
And it was strange it was almost like momentarily in my head the world had stopped because everything I'd strive to have and achieve in my life had almost been put on hold.
I was like I don't know what I'm going to do because I dance eight to ten hours a week.
I do loads of other things and then all of a sudden to be told you can't even go out of your local area was a real shock really.
But I mean yeah the run-up to it was strange because in my head I didn't want it to happen or in my head I didn't want it to happen as quick as it did.
And then there was like I spoke to someone who's close to me, well it was my dance teacher in fact, and she was the same.
She says I can't wrap my head around why people are panicking and I said to her maybe it's just me and you.
And we'd laugh and joke about the fact, not joke about what was going on, we'd joke about the fact that we were so laid back and the rest of the world was in this panic-stricken.
And then suddenly we just kind of went now we understand why but it's because we were just like oh when it happens it happens.
But I think people were preempting the worst before it actually happened so already people were getting anxious about what was going to happen.
Whereas naturally you'd think it would make me really anxious too but in a weird way I couldn't be anxious about something that wasn't real.
Like it hadn't happened, there was no lockdown. People around me were panicked by it yeah.
But other than that I was just like well it's kind of, to me it was almost like when you go to shops at Christmas time people are manic around you because they want to get all the pre-
To me nothing, it didn't really signal to me anything was wrong in the world at that moment in time so I was just kind of you know quite relaxed about it.
But when it hit it hit with full force then because then I was a bit like I almost felt that I didn't get any pre-warning because although other people were panicking and I wasn't and maybe I should have been.
It was kind of strange then to then suddenly be like well no it is real and then I was kind of frustrated at why I didn't accept it was real sooner because then it would have been less of a shock and less of an impact.
But just have to kind of go with it really.
Do you usually live in your own flat independently?
I do.
How has that changed then?
It's changed massively in the fact that if I'm being honest I'm currently not living at my own house, I'm living very much at my parents.
I do go to check my flat and make sure everything's alright, pick up the post, do things that sort of make to make people aware that I haven't just completely left it abandoned.
But it was more a case of when all the lockdowns came in I said to my mum I can't be on my own, I don't want you to be on your own because I had no internet.
Although I had a TV and I had people around me I had no internet and internet has become a massive part of how we communicate now so I'm like if I had been at home and there was no way of me getting to my parents I genuinely have no idea what I'd have done because other than phoning up somebody I would have been completely cut off from the world completely.
Other than the fact that people could talk to me on the phone I wouldn't be able to see them virtually because I wouldn't have, well I do have data on my phone but I wouldn't have been nowhere near enough for me to do what I do now.
And so yeah it was a bit of a shock because obviously coming down to my parents it was a bit stressful because suddenly my dad who works four days a week was suddenly working from home.
As well as myself having to keep up my men cat work and my other job because neither of them were furlough which was good in a way because it gave me something to focus on but in a way it was quite stressful because dad and I were having to make sure we were in opposite ends of the house otherwise we'd hear each other's conversation.
And it just particularly as he was having to record quite a lot of his meetings so he was like it wasn't until they played it back all they could hear was me in the background talking about my work and they were like oh dad was like well we were in different rooms of the house but the house is not majorly big in terms of even if we went upstairs and then again the internet is not great because we're the furthest away from the internet box where we live so it's kind of hit and miss as to who whose call goes because usually if two of us are on a call
at the same time one would cut the other out so it was kind of working out who's more important.
So yeah I'm hoping to go back up into my place at some point but the the fact that the world is so uncertain doesn't make me at the moment doesn't make me feel that going back is the right thing and I'm still trying to look for a place to live in Abercadene.
I haven't found one on the council yet even though there have been many properties on the council I still haven't found one but hopefully fingers crossed it won't be too much longer.

two if the government hasn't said there are any restrictions I can go to a dance class tomorrow
because I've got to give you 24 hours notice so I'm still I'm still controlling in a way of like I
know exactly when the government posts out about restrictions because I've seen the times they get
posted but that's my own thing but other than that emotion wise I'm in a good place now
and I'm quite positive I'm quite happy and I'm quite I'm quite okay with the way things are but
the happy times where it's been really like there were times where because I was so unsure of the
world and so anxious and so kind of my emotions were really confused I was actually lashing out
with people and it was always those that were the closest to me and wanted to help me and wanted me
to be happy that I was doing that too and then I'd do it and then get really upset that I'd done
it but I wasn't that wasn't the emotion I wasn't angry I was confused and lost and didn't know where
I stood but it came out as anger and that's not yeah but I guess you know we all go through the
emotions and I've come the other side now and it is it's one of those it's coming the other side
now but I don't know how long it'll be before it kind of goes round again so I have to wait and see
Do you have have you been able to talk to people have there been people that you've been able to
you know share the way you've been feeling with during this time?
Yeah I'm lucky in a way that mum and dad are quite open and will let me talk but obviously
you never really want to burden your parents but they I do talk to them and we do have conversations
and we're quite open about it but I'm also lucky that my closest friends are a great outlet for me
as well as they as I am for them you know quite often they'll go it's so unfair and like it
sometimes for me it's it's the need to decompress at the end of the day like because there's so much
going on there's so much uncertainty and there's where as my anxiety would come and go there's a
steady anxiety now whereas I'd have moments where I'd almost be free of anxiety because I'd be like
oh you know this is how life is like excuse me pre-Covid I was I had I didn't always have anxiety
I would just have it now you know now and again whereas now there's always there's a there's an
anxiety that there's always like a baseline and then it either go up or it'll go down it'll never
stop and I think it's just because I the world isn't predictable like it used to be people aren't
predictable like they used to be all that predictability has been taken away so therefore
I have nothing to base anything on you know I just I'm just having to literally go oh well
this is what's happened here and now I can't base anything on anything you know and I can't look at
people and know their emotion because quite often that's not their true emotion because nobody wants
to burden anybody else so whilst I'm trying to understand people and work it out because nobody's
being as definitive with their emotions like they're happy they're happy you know you know
whereas actually now people are happy but they're that that's not their emotion if you see what I

to know and more so than ever because now you've got to wear a face mask indoors I can't tell by

my because I don't know whether what I've said has offended them or whether they're happy or

and in that room had a move that connected with themselves physically and it just it

doesn't that just go to show how much people are missing physical contact with another person and

sides of all of these things like with all the rules and everything like that how have you found
kind of making sense of of some of that side of things? Well I um for me the rules have always
been they contradict every rule not every rule but most rules they make contradict themselves
because it's like you say one thing but you like I can't wrap my head around I understand
the economy is important but so are people you know people are more so important than
the economy but I know why they're doing things but they're saying you you know if you've got
restrictions you can't meet people any more than six people at a go um I'm sorry if you've got
restrictions you can't meet anybody you don't live with but yeah I can go down the local pub
as long as I'm out by 10 and I'm like I don't understand the logic I understand they're trying
to keep the economy going and they want people to because what they're saying is we want people to
have that we want people to go to these places because people's mental health is suffering
because they're staying indoors I get that but by saying don't go and have people in your house that
you don't live with you're not eliminating the problem because the problem doesn't stem from
households the problem stems from people going into pubs and restaurants I said if you'd have
just kept it outdoors I know it's freezing cold now but even if you'd if people really wanted a
drink they'd wrap up you'd wear warm clothes you know if you really wanted to I mean I've not been
in the first time I went in a restaurant was in Temby just um just gone yesterday and what day
we'd say Monday not yesterday Saturday and I was petrified I'd never eaten I almost didn't digest
my food um and almost bought it straight back up because I was that anxious I was eating it that
quick because I wanted to get my face mask on because I was so petrified I said to mum what if
we go home and they tell us I've been in contact with someone they said that's 14 days I've got to
not leave this house I said I can't do that I mean I would have to but like the the anxiety of being
forced to stay in in your own four walls for for however many days was like but no the rules are
really I mean I have been lucky in a way and I know this person won't mind me mentioning
I've been so so lucky that Gwen and I have kept contact the way we have just through messages
literally as soon as there's an update even if it doesn't relate to me Gwen literally my phone will
go and I'll be like I can see it on the computer and I'm like any minute now and like it happens I
always get one and Gwen's like you don't need to worry this is what it means and it's great
because I don't I don't listen to any of the conferences because there's too much information
given out at the same time whereas Gwen will listen to all the conferences but will only tell
me things that will affect me whereas if it's not relevant to me she won't tell me because she's like
there's no need for me to tell you something that doesn't involve you so if it involves you
I'll tell you so it's great because then I'm literally Gwen's now become my little messenger
of all things role related because then I'm like I don't need to worry no Gwen's like no you're
fine you're good this is what you need to do to make sure you're you're safe and that's it you
know so I'm I am really lucky. How do you think other people have managed with that side of things?
